security: Revealing Pawley's role as a conduit between anti-Castro Cubans and the U.S. government, even if he denies direct involvement, could compromise deniability and fuel anti-American sentiment. Quoting: "having been connected with the U. S. Government, I can't get involved in revolutionary movements". Also, disclosing specific details of anti-Castro groups' plans for sabotage could jeopardize those operations and endanger individuals involved.
summary: A memorandum detailing a tape-recorded conversation between William D. Pawley and an unidentified Cuban about plans for sabotage against Castro's regime, and Pawley's conversation with AKPACA-1. Pawley expresses skepticism about the feasibility of supporting Cuban revolutionary activities due to disunity among anti-Castro groups and Castro's control.
summary_one_paragraph: On October 20, 1959, Martha Tharpe documented a tape-recorded conversation between William D. Pawley and an unidentified Cuban, believed to be part of a wealthy anti-Castro group, regarding potential sabotage of the upcoming sugar harvest; this conversation took place on October 17-18. The Cuban sought moral backing and funding, revealing contact with General Jose Eleuterio Pedraza's group in the Dominican Republic and plans to organize sabotage in Cuban provinces. Pawley, while acknowledging the worsening Cuban economic situation, discouraged financial support due to the disunity of anti-Castro factions and Castro's firm grip on power, emphasizing his inability to directly involve himself in revolutionary movements given his past U.S. government affiliation.
title: Highlights of Tape-Recorded Conversation in Hand Between Mr. William D. Pawley and an Unidentified Cuban during Period 17-18 October
